title: 108_hr3595
content: The Act may be cited as the "At-Home Infant Care Act of 2004". It includes findings related to infant care. Congress finds that the quality and nature of care-taking in the first months and years of life are critical to a newborn's subsequent development, but there is an extreme shortage of quality, affordable child care for infants. The shortage of quality, affordable infant care is a significant issue, especially in rural areas with a high percentage of low-wage residents. Only 18 percent of the potential need for licensed infant slots is currently being met. Working parents should be able to provide this care themselves without compromising family economic stability. AMENDMENTS TO THE CHILD CARE AND DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANT ACT OF 1990. Authorization of Appropriations for Infant Care at Home under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include necessary funding for fiscal years 2005, 2006, and 2007. Amendments also specify exclusions related to section 658H in the application and plan requirements. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include funding for infant care at home for fiscal years 2005-2007. The amendments specify that funds must supplement, not supplant, non-Federal funds for child care services. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include funding for infant care at home by eligible parent caregivers receiving financial assistance under section 658H. Additionally, activities to improve child care quality exclude section 658H, and funds must supplement non-Federal funds for child care services. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include funding for infant care at home by eligible parent caregivers receiving financial assistance under section 658H. Additionally, activities to improve child care quality exclude section 658H, and funds must supplement non-Federal funds for child care services. Parents.--The Act is amended by inserting after section 658G the following: The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to provide financial assistance for infant care at home by parents under section 658H. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to provide grants for parent caregivers to receive financial assistance to care for infants at home based on demonstrated need. Eligible parents must not receive child care services for the infant and meet specific work hour requirements. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to provide grants for parent caregivers to receive financial assistance to care for infants at home based on demonstrated need. Eligible parents must meet specific work hour requirements, including working 40 hours and attending 20 hours of education or training in a 3-month period, or having both parents work 120 hours in a 3-month period. Additionally, single-parent families must agree to personally care for the infant at home, while two-parent families must agree to do the same. The At-Home Infant Care Act of 2004 amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to provide financial assistance to eligible parents for up to 24 months to care for infants at home. Additionally, a report on at-home infant care must be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of the At-Home Infant Care Act of 2004, evaluating the effectiveness of infant care provided under the Act. The evaluation will include information on states' experiences in developing and operating programs, characteristics of families seeking financial assistance, and the duration of assistance received. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to evaluate the employment patterns and costs and benefits of assistance provided under the Act. (g) Definitions.--The term 'eligible infant' is defined as a child under 2 years old with a family income below 85% of the State median income. Section 658P of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to reflect this definition. Additionally, section 658S is amended to include financial assistance provided under section 658H. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 418(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to exclude section 658H requirements and limitations applicable to assistance provided under the Act.
